items.name: Hand Contours
items.synopsis: As a way to avoid practice drawing from life, I made numerous blind, continuous, and modified hand contour drawings.
items.description: These assignments were a chance for me to practice my still life skills, something I haven't had much experience in doing. The biggest challenge was learning to pace myself properly and also to avoid doing hairy lines.

items.name: First hand
items.description: My first blind contour drawing. I ended up spending too much time on the thumb and then rushing the rest of the hand.

items.name: Interior Lines
items.description: For the second blind contour sketch I was told to focus more on doing interior lines. We were also given more time which let me pace myself better.

items.name: Fist
items.description: Another blind contour. This time I changed my pose to give myself more of a challenge.

items.name: 2nd Hand
items.description: Another 3 minute blind contour. I once again spent too much time on the thumb and then rushed the rest of the hand.

items.name: Continuous
items.description: After doing blind contours, the class moved onto doing continuous line countours. As I could look at the paper, I was able to join the entire hand together as one cohesive piece.

items.name: Continuous 2
items.description: Another continuous line drawing. I switched up the pose again because I wanted to practice getting the bends in the fingers right.

items.name: Modified
items.description: Modified contour drawing. I'm especially proud of the wrinkles around the thumb.

items.name: Polygon Mesh
items.description: The last hand drawing we did was cross-contour. As I wanted to practice my modelling skills, I decided to make mine as if it was a wireframe render.

items.name: Contour Still Life
items.synopsis: As part of an assignment in my art class, I decided to make a still life in the style of a 3D wireframe render.
items.description: Although the topology is terrible, It was an interesting challenge trying to imply the curve in the objects.

items.name: Still Life
items.description: The complete still life. There are a few perspective issues in certain areas, but I'm very happy with how the piece looks.

items.name: Reference
items.description: Since multiple classes needed to use the objects, I had to draw from a reference photo. However, I did spend time analysing their form whilst doing the topology lines.

items.name: Value Head
items.synopsis: As part of our value unit in my art class, we had to do value drawings of the head.
items.description: I had never done a proper portrait drawing before so this was a new experience for me. I especially enjoyed the blending technique as It was the easiest for me to add and subtract value.

items.name: Head
items.description: The final piece. I'm especially proud of the blending I was able to achieve in the hair.

items.name: Reference
items.description: The reference image. Taking this took much longer than it should have (I couldn't pose).

items.name: Progress photo
items.description: A photo of me working on my face. I decided to do the hair last as I knew it would be the most difficult to shade.

items.name: Light Study
items.synopsis: A lighting study I did in the style of Rembrant. I wanted to experiment with painting light on black instead of the traditional technique of painting on white.
items.description: The piece only took an hour, I was bored one evening and felt like doing a painting so I grabbed a canvas and some paints and started playing around.

items.name: Study
items.description: The full composition. Halfway through painting I decided to paint a hole in the center of the pot, but I feel that I didn't paint enough light for it to be noticable.

items.name: AP Sketchbook
items.synopsis: As part of my AP 2D Art & Design submission, I had to create sketchbook pieces that show my train of thought.
items.description: I didn't do many sketchbook pieces as I prefer to plan things out in my head and inside 3D scenes, but it was a good learning experience. Hopefully I'll do more sketchbook work in the future.

items.name: Tree study
items.description: I used this page to understand how to paint trees, rocks, and grass. From this piece I learnt how easy it is to fake detail with simple brush strokes.

items.name: Am I good
items.description: One of my final artworks consisted of a combination of photography and CGI. This page was used to help plan out how I wanted to create the scene.

items.name: A teaching moment
items.description: This page consisted of more compositional and colour planning. I had already envisioned how I wanted the shot to look, but I wanted to write it down to show other people.

items.name: A last breath
items.description: This page didn't hold as much planning as the other pieces. Instead, I used it to plan out what kind of assets I wanted to place in the scene.

items.name: Sketchbook Pieces
items.synopsis: A collection of my sketchbook pieces.
items.description: As I usually create my digital art straight from my head, I have very few pieces in my sketchbooks. However these were the best ones that I could find.

items.name: LDR
items.description: A drawing of K-VRC. I really enjoyed watching LOVE DEATH + ROBOTS and wanted to practice my sketching skills with one of the characters.

items.name: Remote
items.description: A still life drawing of my air conditioner remote.

items.name: Figure
items.description: A still life drawing of a wooden manikin.

items.name: Hallway
items.description: A 1 point perspective drawing I did when exploring an idea for a short animation.

items.name: Character Shapes
items.description: Exploring with how the shape of a character determines their personality.

items.name: Ukulele
items.description: A still life drawing of my ukulele.

items.name: Trip to the Beach
items.synopsis: Using watercolors, I wanted to create a foggy beach environment. This piece was a chance for me to play around with composition, emphasis, and a new medium.
items.description: I have always loved atmospheric environments, and I wanted try to and give dull, cold environment a sort of beauty.

items.name: Thumbnail Sketch
items.description: A thumbnail sketch of the piece. I wanted to mimic the style of old photos by contrasting the vibrant color of the car with a flat environment.

items.name: Foreground rocks
items.description: I then started sketching out the environment on larger paper. To draw the rocks, I imagined that I was joining a bunch of cubes together like I would in Blender.

items.name: Sketch
items.description: After finishing the rocks, I added the car to the scene. I chose a VW Beetle because it helped solidify the 'old photo' style.

items.name: Animation
items.description: I decided to create the artwork in Unreal Engine 5 as well to see how it would look 'realisticly'. I was able to put alot more emphasis on the red than in the watercolor piece.

items.name: Figure Drawings
items.synopsis: Coming Soon!

items.name: City Racing
items.synopsis: I had always wanted to do a high energy car chase animation. So one day I sat down and did it!
items.description: This project was a fun challenge for me as I wanted to make the audience feel as if they're in the shot. I was able to make a custom car rig which helped a lot with getting the tilt of the car as it swings round. I did not model the car.

items.name: Final Animation
items.description: The final animation. I wasn't able to render it in high quality as it required an insanely high sample count.

items.name: Concept
items.description: The first concept. I ended changing the layout because I wasn't getting the up close action-packed feeling.

items.name: Layout
items.description: The scene layout. I based it off a street in Tokyo.

items.name: Viewport
items.description: I'm very proud of the motion of the car. The sharp swing and the levelling out, all while the wheels kept spinning, was very satisfying.

items.name: Creature Breach
items.synopsis: After spending a couple weeks messing around in Houdini. I decided I wanted to attempt a large scale fluid simulation. I had seen a similar creature breach animation online and felt like learning how to do that myself.
items.description: I primarily used the shelf tools with some minor adjustments, but trying to design it from scratch was too difficult with my processing power at the time.

items.name: Fluid
items.description: The fluid simulation. It took about 72 hours non-stop to bake.

items.name: Base
items.description: The base animation. This was definitely the easiest part of the entire project.

items.name: Saliva
items.description: I also made a saliva simulation for the shot, but I ended up not using it for anything.

items.name: Desert Temple
items.synopsis: After hearing about the full Unreal Engine 5 release, I decided to play around with Megascans and Lumen. I was playing Tomb Raider at the time and wanted to making something that resembled a desert temple.
items.description: Putting the environment together was the easiest part. Most of my time was spent learning how to import animations and avoid excessive VRAM usage.
items.tools: Unreal Engine 5, Quixel Megascans, DaVinci Resolve

items.name: Full Animation
items.description: The full animation. The hardest part was getting the animation to work without breaking the scene.

items.name: Light
items.description: A quick lighting test.

items.name: Wide
items.description: A large shot of the scene. I was able to throw this together in about an hour.

items.name: Ornithopter
items.synopsis: After watching Dune (2021) , I loved the animations for the ornithopters and I had to try it for myself.
items.description: I used the projection mapping hack as I didn't want to texture the entire ornithopter. The animation was a chance for me to 'cheat' in 3D.
items.tools: Blender, Quixel Megascans, After Effects, DaVinci Resolve

items.name: Full Animation
items.description: The full animation. This was done over a single weekend.

items.name: Hack
items.description: The ornithopter using a basic projection mapping hack.

items.name: Wide
items.description: The hardest part of the animation was getting the wings to flutter properly. I also wanted to have the sand react to the ornithopter, but that was too difficult.

items.name: Spiderman Swing
items.synopsis: I had seen numerous Spiderman animations floating around on YouTube, and I remember saying to myself 'I could do that'.
items.description: For this animation, I was able to mess around with Blender's new geometry nodes. I used the system to create and simulate the web. The rest was of the animation was hand animated.

items.name: Full Animation
items.description: The first shot of the animation. I ended up only finishing this one as it was the best in the sequence.

items.name: GL Animation
items.description: The full animation sequence.

items.name: Base Animation
items.description: A basic render of the full animation sequence. I disliked the later shots as they didn't feel as polished as the first one.

items.name: Maui Skit
items.synopsis: Using audio from the Disney film, Moana (2016). I put my own spin on the character Maui.
items.description: I had done a bit of character animation before, but I wanted to do a shot where the subject moves all around the scene. I really enjoyed the scene where Moana meets Maui, so I took the audio and came up with my own version of the scene. The rig came from the Blender Foundation.
items.tools: Blender, Quixel Megascans, After Effects, DaVinci Resolve

items.name: Full Animation
items.description: The finished animation. This was the first time that I had ever properly animated a dynamic character to audio.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: The storyboard animation. I sadly wasn't able to put the same level of personality into the 3D character.

items.name: Blocking
items.description: Blocking. This gave me a good starting place as I wasn't sure how to animate Maui jumping around the scene.

items.name: Refining
items.description: I learnt to animate by continuously interpolating keyframes between poses. The more you interpolate, the smoother the animation.

items.name: Final Viewport Animation
items.description: The final viewport animation. I wasn't too happy with Maui's speed due to the timing and size of the set, but it was a good animation exercise.

items.name: Lighting
items.description: A basic lighting test. I wanted to light the scene similar to early 3D Disney animations.

items.name: Moving Day
items.synopsis: Moving Day was a short animation I made after making random sketches inside of Blender. It explores the idea of what animals consider home.
items.description: Moving Day is one of my favourite pieces, and it happened completely by accident. I was messing around with the annotation tool for concepting, and I ended up sketching a mouse looking into a hole in the attic. From there I started adding assets and lights, and it soon became the animation Moving Day. I even ended up writing a short story about it for an English assignment.

items.name: Final Animation
items.description: The final animation. I was very pleased with how it turned out.

items.name: Sketch
items.description: The original concept. I wanted to contrast the dark environment of an attic with with a warm sunrise glow.

items.name: Paintover
items.description: Once I had finished modelling the attic, I did a paintover sketch in Krita to experiment with what details I wanted to add to the shot.

items.name: Rig
items.description: The mouse. I began with sculpting and then retopologized, textured, rigged, and groomed him.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: A simple 3D storyboard. This let me figure out timing and framing.

items.name: Lighting
items.description: The final viewport animation. This was one of the first times that I had made and used a high quality rig, so I was still learning best animation practices.

items.name: Sci-Fi Plains
items.synopsis: Following the concept art by Thomas Dubois, I decided to experiment with large scale environments using Quixel's Megascans.
items.description: I was scrolling through Artstation and came across a painting by Thomas Dubois. I was transfixed by the lighting and wanted to recreate it inside of Blender. The piece was lots of fun to make (especially the clouds). I ended up sending the piece to Thomas Dubois and he enjoyed it.

items.name: Final Animation
items.description: The final animation.

items.name: Concept
items.description: The original artwork by Thomas Dubois. I did not make this.

items.name: FIX
items.description: A first draft. I wanted to make sure I could ace the highlights on the cliff.

items.name: Grading
items.description: I soon personalised the render by adding a spaceship model from CGTrader.

items.name: Critiques
items.description: For this piece I spent time critiquing my own renders. I sketched over areas I wanted to improve.

items.name: Clouds
items.description: Clouds. This was both difficult and fun to do. I enjoyed creating similar forms to the concept, but I hated having to deal with longer render times.

items.name: Viewport
items.description: The viewport animation.

items.name: A Ghost Story
items.synopsis: A piece I made after seeing the movie, A Ghost Story (2017).
items.description: A Ghost Story (2017) has to be one of my most favourite films. It's relaxing, simple, and the visual aesthetic of it is breathtaking. Soon after I watched it I knew I had to recreate the house. I also made an animation, but it was never completed due to rendering issues.

items.name: FINAL
items.description: The final render. I think it matches the original shot quite well.

items.name: HOUSE
items.description: The house. This was one of my only architectural pieces, and I relied a lot on booleans to get the windows in place.

items.name: Shading
items.description: Shading was quite simple and it wasn't too difficult finding a nice HDRI.

items.name: CRITIQUE
items.description: I also drew notes over my renders to figure out what things I wanted to improve.

items.name: LIGHTING
items.description: I worked especially hard on getting the soft warm glow inside the house.

items.name: TREES
items.description: Originally, I tried using PNGs for the trees, but you could tell they were too flat when looking at them. So I instead used real tree models.

items.name: Animation
items.description: The animation. I wasn't able to render it as the scene was too heavy and I had other projects in the works.

items.name: As the Paint Wears Away
items.synopsis: Racism has been an issue for a very long time, especially in America. This piece was a commentary on the American Dream and how behind all the shiny patriotic paint there's a much deeper systemic problem.
items.description: It was originally meant to be a simple school project during online learning, but I really liked the message I was trying to tell so I put more effort into it.

items.name: Final
items.description: The final piece. The paint represents the American Dream, and the fact it's being worn down is showing all of America's flaws. I chose to remove the eyes and ears from the sculpture to imply that people don't always choose to see and hear to the problem.

items.name: WIP
items.description: The piece without the paint. At that time, I hadn't figured out what I wanted to tell with the piece yet.

items.name: BTS
items.description: A screenshot of the layout.

items.name: P.66
items.synopsis: Inspired by the concept art of Fang Yi, I decided to try and re-create P.66 Probe.
items.description: I saw this concept while scrolling through Arstation and I loved everything about it: the composition, the colour, the atmospherics. I knew I had to try and re-create it. The hardest challenge during this project was having to deal with such a large scale scene. The number of buildings and the volumetrics took a great toll on my rendering speed.

items.name: Final Render
items.description: The final render. I probably would have worked more on it if my computer handled volumetrics better.

items.name: Concept
items.description: The original artwork by Fang Yi. I did not make this.

items.name: Breakdown
items.description: A breakdown of the original piece by Fang Yi. There were a lot of buildings and I wanted to match the concept as closely as possible.

items.name: Buildings
items.description: A viewport render of the finished buildings.

items.name: Clouds
items.description: Figuring out how to do the clouds and mist was extremely challenging.

items.name: New Layout
items.description: I ended up changing the distrbution of the buildings because the previous layout wasn't working.

items.name: Personalized
items.description: By giving myself more creative control and more loosely following the original concept, I was able to improve the scene.

items.name: Viewport Animation
items.description: During this time I also had the idea of making a short horror animation.

items.name: Rendered Animation
items.description: I tried rendering the project, but the sheer number of volumes broke my renders.

items.name: Night Driving
items.synopsis: Night Driving is my submission for the Keep The Cube competition that I helped host for the unofficial Blender Community Discord server.
items.description: Although I've been told the piece is too dark (lighting wise), I still really like the emphasis I was able to create with the lighting. For me, this feels like it could be a still from a movie.

items.name: Final
items.description: The final piece. I find the glow from the fire extremely satisfying.

items.name: First draft
items.description: A first draft. I used physical tree models for the foreground, and then 2D planes for the background.

items.name: Tree Coloring
items.description: I initially wanted to have the scene set during the day, so I spent a lot of time trying to get the trees looking as realistic as possible.

items.name: Full
items.description: I was eventually able to add thickness to the forest so all that could be seen was the cube and the path.

items.name: Concept
items.description: I then drew over the render in Krita to decide how I wanted the lighting to look.

items.name: Mona Lisa
items.synopsis: Mona Lisa was part of a school assignment. The class had to re-create a famous piece of art in a medium of their choice.
items.description: I wanted to have a go at character design so I decided to choose the Mona Lisa. MakeHuman was extremely useful in getting the character looking decent, however I sadly wasn't able to imitate the famous Mona Lisa smile.

items.name: Final Render
items.description: The final render. I sadly ran out of time before I could properly texture her clothing and do the background.

items.name: First draft
items.description: The blocking stage. You can see that I struggled to make a realistic looking face.

items.name: Eevee
items.description: The clothing was also especially hard to do. When I simulated it, there were numerous glitches between the different layers of cloth.

items.name: Small fixes
items.description: Later I was able to fix the face and the clothing.

items.name: Hair
items.description: Doing hair infuriated me. I remember spending hours trying to make it look like something that wasn't a huge mess.

items.name: Let Me Be
items.synopsis: Let Me Be is a piece from my AP 2D Art & Design submission. It was one of my favourites as it was the best mix of digital 2D and 3D.
items.description: I wanted this render to show the affects of grief on an individual. I separated the king from his family using colour and gave him more space on screen to emphasise the idea of pushing out his family.

items.name: Final
items.description: The final piece. I was on a time crunch so I wasn't able to polish the characters as much as I wanted to.

items.name: Original Idea
items.description: The original idea. At first I wanted to separate the king from his family by using pillars, however I liked the idea of using light more.

items.name: NPR
items.description: I went through a stage where I wanted to the piece to look similar to the style of Kung Fu Panda's 2D animations, but I soon realised that NPR would take too much time to perfect.

items.name: Quixel
items.description: I used Quixel Megascans assets to quickly block out the scene. The render was better than what I was doing with NPR, so I switched back to a more photorealistic style.

items.name: Lighting
items.description: This was one of the final 3D renders. Later, I moved the table closer as I felt that the subjects were all too far away.

items.name: Steamboat Willy
items.synopsis: For the #Blender52 theme, Cartoon, I wanted to recreate part of Disney's classic Steamboat Willy (1928).
items.description: I'm especially proud of this piece as it was one of the first times that I was able to create a character without using blueprints. If I could remake the project, I likely would spend more time on the fur.

items.name: Final
items.description: The final render. I threw a bunch of post processing on it to give it a vintage look.

items.name: modelling
items.description: A screenshot of the model. I enjoyed creating a character that wasn't in the typical t-pose.

items.name: fur
items.description: Crazy hair. I wanted Mickey to feel like a real mouse, but I couldn't seem to get the fur to behave.

items.name: Scene
items.description: Mickey in the scene. Since the traditional animation didn't have much detail, I didn't have to spend much time on the set.

items.name: Render
items.description: The pre-comp render. I liked the pop of colour, but I wanted the render to match the original so I desaturated it in Resolve.

items.name: Under The Moon
items.synopsis: Under The Moon was a quick lighting practice project that I did in an evening.
items.description: Originally, I wanted to make the piece in Unreal Engine 5, but I was too frustrated with the wave system so I reverted back to Blender. However, I do plan to make something with Unreal Engine 5's fluids in the future.

items.name: Final
items.description: The final render. The models were all downloaded from PolyHaven and Mixamo.

items.name: concept
items.description: An extremely quick sketch I did to see how I should frame the shot.

items.name: The Girl and the Robot
items.synopsis:
A girl discovers the importance of friendship through a robot she meets in the forest.

(THIS FILM IS CURRENTLY IN PRODUCTION)
items.description: The Girl and the Robot (TGATR) is a short film that a friend and I are making during our final year of high school. We are both interested in film and our parents suggested we work together on our own movie. My one regret is giving myself 35 visual effects shots.
items.tools: Blender, Substance Painter, Nuke, Mocha, DaVinci Resolve

items.name: Poster
items.description: The current poster for the short film.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: A sheet from the 70 page storyboard.

items.name: Character Concept
items.description: An early character concept of Chipp. I wanted to base him off the robot from Tales from the Loop (2020).

items.name: Filming
items.description: An on-set photo from one the dinner scenes. This was the first time that I had ever used lights in a shoot.

items.name: Chipp Turntable
items.description: A turntable animation of Chipp.

items.name: Chipp Sketchfab
items.description: An interactive model of Chipp.

items.name: Animation
items.description: A pre-rendered shot in the film.

items.name: Full VFX Shot
items.description: The same shot, but rendered and comped.

items.name: Nuke Comp
items.description: The compositing workflow for one of the more advanced scenes using Nuke. There is probably a much more efficient way to comp the shot, but it worked.

items.name: Fallout Shopping
items.synopsis: With humanity wiped from existence, a retail robot is finally free to enjoy what he loves most; going shopping!
items.description:
I came up with the idea for Fallout Shopping while at Central Festival in Chiang Mai. I saw a retail bot wandering around one of the shops, and I thought to myself 'What if that robot could explore the entire mall?'. I then spent my summer in England planning out the story, and then animated the entire thing the following month.

Fallout Shopping was showcased at the 2022 Beyond Animation Festival in Bangkok.
items.role: Director, CG Artist, VFX Artist, Editor

items.name: Fallout Shopping
items.description: The full animation took just under 2 full months to make. 1 month for concepting and planning, another for production.

items.name: Synopsis
items.description: A synposis page that I threw together. This helped me determine whether or not I wanted to make Fallout Shopping.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: A video of the storyboard matched to the music. It helped me get my thoughts together and know how long each shot was going to be.

items.name: Concept 1
items.description: A concept page of how I wanted the scenes to look.

items.name: Concept 2
items.description: Another page of concepts. I based most of the scenes off Central Festival in Chiang Mai.

items.name: Concept 3
items.description: Another page of concepts. I never completed outdoor the environment because I thought I could wing it. It ended up being the worst shot in the entire animation.

items.name: Turntable
items.description: A turntable of the retail bot. I never gave him a name, he wasn't cool enough for that.

items.name: Retail Bot Sketchfab
items.description: An interactive model of the retail bot.

items.name: Lighting Test 1
items.description: An early lighting test of the opening shot. I struggled with trying to create a damaged apocalyptic floor.

items.name: Lighting Test 2
items.description: Another early lighting test. This shot gave experience on how to light a hallway with a strong backlight.

items.name: Lighting Test 3
items.description: This shot is what inspired me to make Fallout Shopping. I had imagined it weeks before I considered making it an animation.

items.name: Lamp Attack!
items.synopsis: We've all grown accustomed to the brutality we see in the Pixar intro. But what about those poor Pixar letters everywhere else?
items.description: I was eating lunch one day when I thought to myself 'What if the Pixar lamps were like monsters to the Pixar letters?'. I had always wanted to make something horror inspired, and within a week I had a storyboard planned out for the animation.

items.name: Lamp Attack!
items.description: The entire short film. I was amazed that a dumb idea I had while eating lunch ended up becoming a full short animation.

items.name: Sketch
items.description: The first sketch. The entire animation was built off this one quick drawing.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: This was the first time I made a storyboard for an entire short. As I was working in a team I wanted to show them what we were aiming for.

items.name: Rig
items.description: Rigging the letters was a fun experience for me. There were no tutorials online so my rigging ability was really put to the test.

items.name: Rig Demo
items.description: Rigging Luxo Jr. wasnt' as difficult to rig as there were numerous tutorials.

items.name: Early Animation Test
items.description: Early animation test. I started with just the core actors as I wanted them to look perfect in the final shot.

items.name: Lighting Test
items.description: A lighting test. I wanted the spotlight to be the main source of light as it would give off a more horror-like mood.

items.name: Crowd Test
items.description: Finding a way to animate large crowds was a huge challenge. Here's one of the failed crowd tests.

items.name: Pixar Intro
items.description: While testing the letter and Luxo rigs, I made a mock Pixar intro.

items.name: Sparky
items.synopsis: In a quest to find a new power source for Glenton, a robot finds himself doing more harm than good. Or so it seems...
items.description: Sparky was the only short film that was made by BOAP Studios. Although I was given the role of producer, I was heavily involved in writing, modelling, and animating. This was the first time that I got to work with other artists.

items.name: Sparky
items.description: The entire short film took about 16 months to make.

items.name: Early Concept
items.description: An early concept of Sparky. I thew this together as a test to see how his limbs would interact with the surroundings.

items.name: Street
items.description: A screenshot of the road scene. A lot of duplication and moving of houses was done for this.

items.name: Animation
items.description: A screenshot of Sparky during the animation phase. We went for more tube based limbs so we could stretch Sparky as much as we needed.

items.name: Turbines
items.description: An early shot of the turbines. The mountain was everntually removed from the shot but the rest of the scene is relatively similar to the final.

items.name: Warehouse
items.description: An interior image of the warehouse. Getting optimized render settings for this scene was extremely difficult due to the amount of render noise.

items.name: Breeze Render Engine
items.synopsis: Breeze Render Engine is a C++ application that allows artists to create scenes in OpenGL and then render them out with Breeze's custom render engine.
items.description: After following the Ray Tracing in One Weekend tutorial series, I became hooked on understanding how digital content creators used maths to display 3D models. This led me to learn about OpenGL, and I quickly found some lessons on how it worked. After some time, I decided to make a rendering engine. Breeze Render Engine is my first ever C++ and Qt application. I spent around 8 months creating the engine with multiple rewrites. It was difficult, but I'm proud of how much I was able to learn.

items.name: Scene Example
items.description: A screenshot of a scene made in Breeze. You can download and try the application from my Github page.

items.name: Demo Video
items.description: A demo video of Breeze in action.

items.name: OBJ Importing
items.description: Breeze also allows custom OBJ importing.

items.name: Render
items.description: The render from the demo video.

items.name: Sicle Maps App
items.synopsis: Sicle is a simplified alternative to Google Maps. Users can track their location and follow routes to their desired destination.
items.description: After seeing some modern app designs on Dribbble, I was inspired to write my own mobile application. Since I'm an avid cyclist, I wanted to make an application that I could use. The solution was a simplified Google Maps application called Sicle. While creating Sicle , I was able to understand how to use Android Studio, and how to build and run Kotlin code.

items.name: App Screenshot
items.description: A screenshot of the app in use.

items.name: App Demo Video
items.description: The app runs on Android and uses the MapBox API.

items.name: School Designs
items.synopsis: I was given the opportunity at Chiang Mai International School to add my own personal touch to some walls! My designs can now be seen in the high school art classroom and the school gym.
items.description: After completing my submission for AP 2D Art & Design , my art teacher suggested that I decorate the art room pillars. During that time, I was also approached by the school to make designs for the school gym. I jumped at the chance to leave a legacy at Chiang Mai International School , and by the start of the next school year, both projects were completed.

items.name: Pillars
items.description: A photo of both completed pillars. We named the closest one 'Boogle' and the other 'Night Sky'.

items.name: First Pillar
items.description: A photo of me painting 'Boogle'. Although I worked with a couple of other students on the pillars, 'Boogle' was primarily my piece.

items.name: Polaroid
items.description: A polaroid of me painting 'Night Sky' with my art teacher and a couple of other students. We only had a week before school ended for the summer so it was all hands on deck.

items.name: Painting Video
items.description: A video I took while painting. At the time I was staying an extra 2 hours after school each day to get the project done.

items.name: Measuring Walls
items.description: A photo taken of me when I was estimating how large the designs should be on the gym wall.

items.name: Full Frame
items.description: A full frame shot of the gym that I composited together inside of Nuke. I used this image to pitch the idea to the School Board.

items.name: Real Full
items.description: A real photo of the designs in the school gym. I was pleasantly surprised to see them there on my first day back to school.

items.name: Real Full 2
items.description: Another angle of the real designs.

items.name: Website
items.synopsis: I custom built this website! With HTML, CSS, Javascript and a lot of love, everything you see here was programmed by me.
items.description: I had always wanted to make my own website. I learnt the basics of web design in 2019, but since then I hadn't used them for anything useful. One day I sat down and decided to put that knowledge to good use, and after a year of designing, building, redesigning and rebuilding, I finally built a website that I'm proud of.

items.name: Home Page
items.description: The wonderful home page.
